Problem:
We consider the behavior of a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + i y(t) \\), evolving under a linear transformation described by the matrix \\( A \\) applied on the vector representation \\( (x, y) \\). An integral transformation \\( T \\) defined by \\( T[z] = \\int_{0}^{t} e^{-st} z(u) du \) is studied, where \\( s \\) is a constant complex number.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), a new transformation defined by a matrix \\( B \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\), and we observe \\( T[z(T)] \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\), will this outcome depend solely on the transformations \\( A \\) and not on \\( B \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with a new transformation matrix \\( B \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) imparts a new behavior on \\( z(t) \\) post-\\( t_1 \\), affecting its trajectory and therefore the resultant integral \\( T[z(T)] \\. As a result, the outcome will depend on both \\( A \\) and \\( B \\), reflecting their combined influence on the trajectory of \\( z(t) \\).
